channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Despite Crackdown, Path to Join ISIS Often Winds Through Porous Turkish Border
item.description: The Turkish government has improved efforts to stop foreign militants from crossing into Syria, but Western governments say Turkey has not gone far enough.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkish police officers guarded the border near Suruc, Turkey, last fall. The authorities have cracked down on foreign fighters heading into Syria, but many still pass through.

item.title: Quiet Start to E.C.B. Bond-Buying Program for the Eurozone
item.description: Known as quantitative easing, the purchases are meant to stimulate the economy and help reignite the region’s dangerously low inflation rate.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Benoît Coeuré, a member of the central bank’s Executive Board, said the asset purchase program had already pushed down the cost of credit.

item.title: Greece’s Debt Talks Will Move to More Technical Level
item.description: On Wednesday, Greece will begin talks in Brussels directly with representatives of the three creditor groups, the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: The Bank of Greece in Athens on Monday. The country could run out of money before the end of this month.

item.title: Militants Kill Three Police Officers in Egypt as Violent Attacks Spread
item.description: The violence was part of a campaign of attacks on businesses and security forces by Islamist militants who have pledged allegiance to the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Former Sarkozy Aide Charged in Fraud, as Inquiry into Illegal Campaign Funding Continues
item.description: Claude Guéant, a top aide to former President Nicolas Sarkozy, was accused by a judge in Paris of forgery and laundering proceeds from tax fraud.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: White House Faults G.O.P. Senators’ Letter to Iran’s Leaders
item.description: The letter, signed by 47 Republican senators, warns Iran’s leaders that a nuclear agreement now being negotiated by the Obama administration may not last without congressional approval.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Chad and Niger Troops Attack Nigeria's Boko Haram Extremists
item.description: Soldiers from Chad and Niger launched the largest international push to defeat Nigeria's Islamic extremists whose war has spilled over into neighboring countries, officials and witnesses said Monday. Chad's president has warned that the leader of Boko Haram must surrender or be killed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Stolen Michelangelo Documents Are Offered to Vatican, for a Price
item.description: A seller approached a cardinal with an odd proposition: Would he be interested in two documents written by the hand of Michelangelo?
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Lens Blog: Making Egypt’s Streets Safe for Women
item.description: Eman Helal hopes to not only document the widespread harassment of women on Cairo’s streets, but she also aims to spur changes in public attitudes and behavior.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Women usually prefer to use the ladies subway cars for fear of being harassed in the crowded cars of men.

item.title: Contrary to Earlier Assertions, Putin Suggests Plan to Reclaim Crimea Began in February 2014
item.description: Remarks by the Russian leader contradict his claims that he awaited referendum results before moving to reclaim Crimea from Ukraine last year.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Russian soldiers surrounded a Ukrainian base in Perevalnoye, Crimea, last year. The Russian role in annexing Crimea led to the worst crisis in relations between Russia and the West since the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991.

item.title: Obama Freezes Assets of Seven Venezuelan Officials
item.description: The White House said in a statement that the government officials were implicated in human rights violations in Venezuela.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Air of Mystery Surrounds an Unlikely Source in Britain: the Crufts Dog Show
item.description: Thendara Satisfaction, an Irish setter also known as Jagger, died after returning home from the Crufts dog show, and its owners say it was poisoned.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Dee Milligan-Bott, second from right, co-owner of the Irish setter Thendara Satisfaction, spoke to reporters in Kilby, England, on Monday.

item.title: Kurdish Forces Attack Islamic State West of Kirkuk
item.description: Kurdish forces drove Islamic State militants back from the oil-rich city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq on Monday, in an advance backed by heavy air strikes from a U.S.-led coalition.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: In Chávez, Maduro Trusts, Maybe to His Detriment and Venezuela’s
item.description: As an economic crisis worsens, what was once President Nicolás Maduro’s greatest advantage — loyalty to his predecessor — may be his greatest handicap.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, center, at a military parade in February commemorating the 23rd anniversary of a failed coup in which President Hugo Chávez participated as an Army officer.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Baidu Users Object to Women’s Day Logo
item.description: The Chinese search company featured on its home page a princess doll twirling on top of a music box surrounded by jewelry and other accessories, while Google had an array of women excelling in various professions.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Hostesses for the annual legislative sessions in Beijing gathered in front of the Great Hall of the People before the opening of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference on March 3.

item.title: South Korea Split Over How to React to Attack on U.S. Ambassador Mark Lippert
item.description: The initial contrition, led by a parade of conservative South Koreans, has now provoked a backlash, with accusations that the government is “worshiping” America.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean veterans rallied to denounce the attack on Mark W. Lippert, the American envoy, in Seoul. Many from the country's older generation regard the United States as a savior.

item.title: U.N. Finds ‘Alarmingly High’ Levels of Violence Against Women
item.description: Despite progress for women on other fronts, violence is a persistent problem, with about 35 percent of women saying they have been attacked, a United Nations report says.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan women who cannot return to their homes live in a shelter run by Women for Afghan Women in Kabul.

item.title: Memo From Afghanistan: Afghan Peace Efforts Reopen Wounds Over Pakistan
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani is seeking to pressure the Taliban to join peace talks by intensively courting Pakistan’s military, though critics distrust Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan in Islamabad, Pakistan, last November. Some Afghans firmly see Pakistan as an enemy and have been surprised by the president’s concessions.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Embracing the Other Italy
item.description: Could the flow of young Italian emigrants somehow become a remedy for their country's malaise?
item.dc:creator: MARCO MANCASSOLA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Britain’s Time of Turbulence
item.description: Alienated voters faced with some uninspiring choices make for a radically unpredictable election.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA
